postVideoDialogue.speaker: VOLT
postVideoDialogue.text: Modbus. DNP3. Protocols designed in the '70s and '90s. No authentication. No encryption. Just... trust.

postVideoDialogue.speaker: GHOST
postVideoDialogue.text: I used to love these protocols. Get on the network, and you can read anything, write anything. No credentials needed.

postVideoDialogue.speaker: BLAZE
postVideoDialogue.text: Wait, these protocols are still in use? In 2087? Controlling an OIL REFINERY?

postVideoDialogue.speaker: CIPHER
postVideoDialogue.text: Legacy systems. Can't replace them without rebuilding the entire facility. So we compensate with network controls.

postVideoDialogue.speaker: CIPHER
postVideoDialogue.text: But Wiretap specializes in protocol exploitation. They're not breaking INTO the network - they're speaking the protocols' own language.

postVideoDialogue.speaker: NARRATOR
postVideoDialogue.text: [You can now explore Protocol Port. Learn about ICS protocols from the NPCs before confronting Wiretap.]

initial.speaker: kim
initial.text: *headset on, analyzing packet captures* CyberGuard? Perfect timing. I've been watching the strangest traffic patterns.

initial.speaker: kim
initial.text: I'm Kim, communications engineer. If it moves bits in this refinery, I know about it. Or I SHOULD know about it.

modbus.speaker: kim
modbus.text: Modbus! The granddaddy of ICS protocols. Developed by Modicon in 1979. Yes, 1979.

modbus.speaker: kim
modbus.text: Simple, efficient, universal. Every PLC vendor supports it. That's why it's everywhere.

modbus.speaker: kim
modbus.text: Modbus RTU runs over serial - RS-485 usually. Modbus TCP runs over Ethernet on port 502.

modbus.speaker: GHOST
modbus.text: Port 502. First thing I scan for when looking for ICS. Wide open on so many networks.

modbus.speaker: kim
modbus.text: The problem? Modbus has ZERO security features. No authentication. No encryption. Nothing.

modbus.speaker: kim
modbus.text: Anyone on the network can read coils, write registers, stop/start PLCs. Just need to send the right bytes.

modbus.speaker: BLAZE
modbus.text: And this controls REFINERIES? With no passwords?!

modbus.speaker: kim
modbus.text: In 1979, if you were in the control room, you were authorized. The network WAS the security. Now... not so much.

options.text: Why are these protocols so insecure?

dnp3.speaker: kim
dnp3.text: DNP3 - Distributed Network Protocol version 3. The utility industry's favorite.

dnp3.speaker: kim
dnp3.text: Designed for SCADA systems with unreliable communications - think substations connected by radio or satellite.

dnp3.speaker: kim
dnp3.text: It handles dropped packets, out-of-order delivery, all the problems with long-distance communications.

dnp3.speaker: kim
dnp3.text: Standard port is 20000. You'll find it in power grids, water systems, pipelines - anywhere with remote sites.

dnp3.speaker: kim
dnp3.text: Originally? None. But they added Secure Authentication - DNP3-SA. Challenge-response to prevent spoofing.

dnp3.speaker: kim
dnp3.text: Problem is, SA is optional. Many installations don't enable it. Or they enable it but use weak keys.

dnp3.speaker: kim
dnp3.text: Wiretap knows this. They're specifically targeting our DNP3 links to remote pump stations.

options.text: Why are ICS protocols so insecure?

why_insecure.speaker: kim
why_insecure.text: Why are ICS protocols insecure? Context. Historical context.

why_insecure.speaker: kim
why_insecure.text: 1979 - Modbus created. 1993 - DNP3 released. Networks were isolated. Physical access WAS authentication.

why_insecure.speaker: kim
why_insecure.text: No internet connectivity. No remote access. If you could send commands, you were standing in the control room.

why_insecure.speaker: VOLT
why_insecure.text: Then IT/OT convergence happened. Corporate wanted data. Remote access for vendors. Integration with business systems.

why_insecure.speaker: kim
why_insecure.text: Suddenly these protocols designed for trusted, isolated networks were exposed to... everything.

why_insecure.speaker: kim
why_insecure.text: And you can't just 'add security' to Modbus. The spec has no room for it. Every device would need replacement.

why_insecure.speaker: kim
why_insecure.text: So we compensate. Network segmentation. Deep packet inspection. Protocol-aware firewalls. Monitoring.

why_insecure.speaker: kim
why_insecure.text: We can't fix the protocols. So we protect the network they run on.

options.text: Let's put that knowledge to use.

ready_check.speaker: kim
ready_check.text: Wiretap is somewhere in our network, capturing traffic. They've been replaying commands, testing what they can control.

ready_check.speaker: kim
ready_check.text: Talk to Rodriguez in the field - he's seen some weird behavior on remote equipment. And Morgan in the SOC has been tracking the traffic patterns.

ready_check.speaker: kim
ready_check.text: Watch yourself. Wiretap speaks protocol fluently. They won't just break in - they'll BE a legitimate-looking device.

practiceQuestions.question: What TCP port does Modbus TCP typically use?
practiceQuestions.hint: It's a well-known ICS port - not a common IT port like HTTP or SSH.

practiceQuestions.question: What built-in security features does original Modbus have?
practiceQuestions.hint: It was designed in 1979 for isolated networks...

initial.speaker: rodriguez
initial.text: *wiping grease off hands* CyberGuard? Out here in the field? Must be serious.

initial.speaker: rodriguez
initial.text: I'm Rodriguez. I maintain the instruments and field devices. The stuff that actually touches the process.

initial.speaker: rodriguez
initial.text: Something's been messing with my equipment. Remote valves opening when they shouldn't. Setpoints changing.

fieldbus.speaker: rodriguez
fieldbus.text: Fieldbus protocols - the ones that run at Levels 0 and 1. Connecting controllers to actual field devices.

fieldbus.speaker: rodriguez
fieldbus.text: HART - runs over the same 4-20mA wiring as analog signals. Digital data riding on top of analog.

fieldbus.speaker: rodriguez
fieldbus.text: Foundation Fieldbus - digital from the start. Used a lot in process industries like ours.

fieldbus.speaker: rodriguez
fieldbus.text: Profibus - big in manufacturing and Europe. Good for high-speed automation.

fieldbus.speaker: VOLT
fieldbus.text: These are the protocols that talk directly to sensors and actuators. The lowest level of the stack.

fieldbus.speaker: rodriguez
fieldbus.text: Security? Same story as Modbus. These were designed for dedicated, isolated networks. Not security threats.

fieldbus.speaker: rodriguez
fieldbus.text: But if someone gets access to the fieldbus network... they can talk directly to my valves and transmitters.

serial_ethernet.speaker: rodriguez
serial_ethernet.text: Big shift happened over the last 20 years. Serial to Ethernet. Changed everything.

serial_ethernet.speaker: rodriguez
serial_ethernet.text: Serial - RS-232, RS-485. Point-to-point or multidrop. Physical access usually required.

serial_ethernet.speaker: GHOST
serial_ethernet.text: Serial meant I had to be ON SITE. Physically connected to that cable. Hard to attack remotely.

serial_ethernet.speaker: rodriguez
serial_ethernet.text: Then Ethernet came to the plant floor. Same protocols - Modbus TCP, EtherNet/IP, Profinet - but over standard networking.

serial_ethernet.speaker: rodriguez
serial_ethernet.text: Benefits were huge. Standard cabling. Standard switches. Easy integration. Remote diagnostics.

serial_ethernet.speaker: rodriguez
serial_ethernet.text: But now an attacker doesn't need physical access. Just network access. Could be from across the world.

serial_ethernet.speaker: BLAZE
serial_ethernet.text: So we traded physical security for... convenience?

serial_ethernet.speaker: rodriguez
serial_ethernet.text: Pretty much. Now we need network security to replace what physical isolation used to give us.

wireless.speaker: rodriguez
wireless.text: Wireless in ICS. Controversial topic. Some people love it, some people won't touch it.

wireless.speaker: rodriguez
wireless.text: WirelessHART - industrial wireless protocol. Mesh networking, designed for process automation. We use it for some remote sensors.

wireless.speaker: rodriguez
wireless.text: ISA100 - another industrial wireless standard. Similar use cases.

wireless.speaker: rodriguez
wireless.text: Regular WiFi is out here too. Operators with tablets, maintenance laptops. Convenient but risky.

wireless.speaker: CIPHER
wireless.text: Wireless means the attacker doesn't need to plug into anything. Just be in radio range.

wireless.speaker: rodriguez
wireless.text: Exactly. I've found unauthorized WiFi access points out here. 'Rogue' APs someone plugged in for convenience.

wireless.speaker: rodriguez
wireless.text: Wiretap could be anywhere. Doesn't need to be inside the fence. Just needs line of sight to our wireless.

ready_check.speaker: rodriguez
ready_check.text: My equipment started acting weird three days ago. Valves moving a few percent. Flow setpoints drifting.

ready_check.speaker: rodriguez
ready_check.text: Small changes. Testing what they can do. Learning the process.

ready_check.speaker: rodriguez
ready_check.text: Morgan in the SOC has packet captures. She can show you exactly what Wiretap's been doing.

ready_check.speaker: rodriguez
ready_check.text: Find them fast. An oil refinery isn't something you want someone playing with.

practiceQuestions.question: What is a key security difference between serial and Ethernet ICS communications?
options: Serial requires physical access; Ethernet can be accessed remotely
practiceQuestions.hint: Think about what network connectivity enables...

practiceQuestions.question: At which Purdue levels do fieldbus protocols typically operate?
practiceQuestions.hint: Fieldbus connects controllers to field devices - the lowest levels.

initial.speaker: morgan
initial.text: *surrounded by monitors, dark circles under eyes* CyberGuard. I've been tracking Wiretap for 72 hours straight.

initial.speaker: morgan
initial.text: Morgan. Network security. I analyze traffic, hunt threats, and drink too much coffee.

initial.speaker: morgan
initial.text: I've got Wiretap's traffic signature. I know what they're doing. I just can't stop them yet.

options.text: How do you analyze ICS traffic?

attacks.speaker: morgan
attacks.text: Wiretap is running the classics. Man-in-the-middle. Replay attacks. Protocol spoofing.

attacks.speaker: morgan
attacks.text: Man-in-the-middle - they've positioned themselves between a PLC and the HMI. Reading all traffic, modifying what they want.

attacks.speaker: morgan
attacks.text: The HMI thinks it's talking to the PLC. The PLC thinks it's talking to the HMI. Both are talking to Wiretap.

attacks.speaker: GHOST
attacks.text: Classic MITM. No encryption means they can read and modify anything in transit.

attacks.speaker: morgan
attacks.text: Replay attacks too. They captured legitimate 'open valve' commands and replay them at will.

attacks.speaker: morgan
attacks.text: The PLC doesn't know the command is a recording. No timestamps, no sequence numbers in Modbus.

attacks.speaker: morgan
attacks.text: And spoofing - forging commands that look like they come from legitimate sources. Modbus doesn't verify sender identity.

options.text: How do you analyze this traffic?
I've heard enough. Let's end this.

analysis.speaker: morgan
analysis.text: Wireshark is my best friend. Packet capture and protocol analysis. Has dissectors for Modbus, DNP3, most ICS protocols.

analysis.speaker: morgan
analysis.text: I capture traffic at key network points, then analyze for anomalies.

analysis.speaker: morgan
analysis.text: Anomalies like... function codes that shouldn't be used. Read requests to memory ranges that contain passwords.

analysis.speaker: CIPHER
analysis.text: So you need to know what NORMAL traffic looks like to spot ABNORMAL?

analysis.speaker: morgan
analysis.text: Exactly. Baseline first. Know your normal. Then deviations jump out.

analysis.speaker: morgan
analysis.text: That engineering workstation never sends commands at 3 AM. But last night? 3 AM command burst.

analysis.speaker: morgan
analysis.text: Wiretap thought they were being stealthy. But the traffic PATTERN gave them away.

analysis.speaker: morgan
analysis.text: ICS-specific monitoring tools help too. They understand protocol semantics, not just packet structure.

defenses.speaker: morgan
defenses.text: Defenses against protocol attacks? Can't fix the protocols, so we protect around them.

defenses.speaker: morgan
defenses.text: Network segmentation first. Limit who can even REACH the protocols. Micro-segmentation around critical assets.

defenses.speaker: morgan
defenses.text: Protocol-aware firewalls. They understand ICS protocols. Can filter by function code, register range, even values.

defenses.speaker: morgan
defenses.text: For example: 'Allow Modbus reads from HMI to PLC. Block Modbus writes from anywhere except the engineering workstation.'

defenses.speaker: VOLT
defenses.text: Smart. The firewall understands the protocol's meaning, not just ports and IPs.

defenses.speaker: morgan
defenses.text: Encrypted tunnels can help too. Wrap insecure protocols in VPN or TLS. The protocol is still insecure, but the tunnel isn't.

defenses.speaker: morgan
defenses.text: And monitoring. Always monitoring. You can't prevent everything, but you CAN detect and respond quickly.

options.text: How do you analyze the traffic?
Time to put this knowledge to work.

ready_check.speaker: morgan
ready_check.text: I've traced Wiretap's traffic to a compromised network switch in the process area. They're using it as their pivot point.

ready_check.speaker: morgan
ready_check.text: All their MITM and replay attacks originate from there. Cut them off, and they lose their position.

ready_check.speaker: morgan
ready_check.text: They know protocols inside and out. Be ready for trick questions - they'll try to confuse you about how these systems actually work.

ready_check.speaker: NARRATOR
ready_check.text: [You've learned from all NPCs. The boss arena is now unlocked. Prepare to confront Wiretap!]

practiceQuestions.question: What type of attack intercepts and potentially modifies communications between two parties?
practiceQuestions.hint: The attacker sits 'in the middle' between the communicating parties...

practiceQuestions.question: What is the MOST effective mitigation for insecure legacy ICS protocols?
practiceQuestions.hint: Can't fix the protocols, so we protect the network around them...

dialogue.speaker: WIRETAP
dialogue.text: *voice crackling through speakers* Sssssh. Did you hear that? That was your pump station sending me its secrets.

dialogue.speaker: WIRETAP
dialogue.text: I am WIRETAP. I don't need to break encryption - there isn't any. I just... listen. And speak.

dialogue.speaker: BLAZE
dialogue.text: You've been manipulating equipment. Playing with an oil refinery like it's a toy!

dialogue.speaker: WIRETAP
dialogue.text: Playing? I've been LEARNING. Every Modbus register. Every DNP3 point. I know your process better than your operators.

dialogue.speaker: WIRETAP
dialogue.text: Function code 5 - write single coil. Function code 6 - write single register. Function code 16 - write multiple registers. Shall I demonstrate?

dialogue.speaker: CIPHER
dialogue.text: You know protocols. Let's see if you know how to defend against someone who understands them too.

dialogue.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogue.text: [BOSS BATTLE: WIRETAP - Protocol Exploiter] [30-second timer per question!]

dialogue.speaker: WIRETAP
dialogue.text: No! The protocols were PERFECT attack vectors! No authentication! No encryption! How did you--

dialogue.speaker: GHOST
dialogue.text: The protocols are weak. But the DEFENDERS aren't. Knowing the vulnerabilities means knowing how to watch for exploitation.

dialogue.speaker: WIRETAP
dialogue.text: *connection degrading* This isn't over... The Null Syndicate has greater plans... Null Prime is coming...

dialogue.speaker: WIRETAP
dialogue.text: They don't just understand networks and protocols... they understand EVERYTHING... nation-state level...

dialogue.speaker: VOLT
dialogue.text: Null Prime? That sounds like their leader. An APT-level threat.

dialogue.speaker: CIPHER
dialogue.text: We've stopped a script kiddie, a network infiltrator, and a protocol exploiter. If Null Prime is coming... we need to be ready for something much worse.

dialogue.speaker: BLAZE
dialogue.text: Then we train. We prepare. We learn everything we can about ICS security.

dialogue.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogue.text: [PROTOCOL PORT COMPLETE - MVP Campaign Finished!]

dialogue.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogue.text: [Thank you for playing ICS Defender Chronicles! Future updates will add Supervisory Station, Governance Garrison, and the Final Fortress.]

dialogue.speaker: CIPHER
dialogue.text: Three cities secured. Three Null Syndicate operatives neutralized. But this was just the beginning.

dialogue.speaker: VOLT
dialogue.text: You've learned the fundamentals - what ICS is, how networks should be architected, why protocols are vulnerable.

dialogue.speaker: GHOST
dialogue.text: But there's more. Windows systems. Linux hardening. Governance and compliance. Incident response.

dialogue.speaker: BLAZE
dialogue.text: The fight to protect critical infrastructure never ends. But now you're equipped to join it.

dialogue.speaker: CIPHER
dialogue.text: Welcome to CyberGuard, defender. The world's critical infrastructure is counting on people like you.

dialogue.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogue.text: [End of MVP Campaign - Continue learning with SANS ICS410!]
